mn68:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati naḷakapāne palāsavane.
mn68:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans near Naḷakapāna in the grove of flame-of-the-forest trees.
mn68:1.2.comm: The Buddha is recorded as visiting this grove in two other discourses, which share a common narrative; both deal with the growth of spiritual qualities (AN 10.67, AN 10.68).

mn68:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā kulaputtā bhagavantaṃ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā honti—
mn68:2.1.eng: Now at that time several very well-known gentlemen had gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha’s name—
mn68:2.1.comm: This makes it sound like they had gone forth recently, which would date this discourse to the early years of the dispensation.

mn68:2.2.pli: āyasmā ca anuruddho, āyasmā ca bhaddiyo, āyasmā ca kimilo, āyasmā ca bhagu, āyasmā ca koṇḍañño, āyasmā ca revato, āyasmā ca ānando, aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā kulaputtā.
mn68:2.2.eng: The venerables Anuruddha, Bhaddiya, Kimbila, Bhagu, Koṇḍañña, Revata, Ānanda, and other very well-known gentlemen.
mn68:2.2.comm: Pali editions vary a little in the exact monks mentioned.

mn68:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
mn68:3.1.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting in the open, surrounded by the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn68:3.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā te kulaputte ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn68:3.2.eng: Then the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about those gentlemen:

mn68:3.3.pli: “ye te, bhikkhave, kulaputtā mamaṃ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, kacci te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū abhiratā brahmacariye”ti?
mn68:3.3.eng: “Mendicants, those gentlemen who have gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness in my name—I trust they’re satisfied with the spiritual life?”

mn68:3.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
mn68:3.4.eng: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.

mn68:3.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā te kulaputte ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn68:3.5.eng: For a second and a third time the Buddha asked the same question.

mn68:3.6.pli: “ye te, bhikkhave, kulaputtā mamaṃ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, kacci te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū abhiratā brahmacariye”ti?

mn68:3.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.

mn68:3.8.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā te kulaputte ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:

mn68:3.9.pli: “ye te, bhikkhave, kulaputtā mamaṃ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, kacci te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū abhiratā brahmacariye”ti?

mn68:3.10.pli: Tatiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
mn68:3.10.eng: For a third time, the mendicants kept silent.

mn68:4.1.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

mn68:4.2.eng: “Why don’t I question just those gentlemen?”
mn68:4.2.comm: Reading te va as in PTS. Here the Buddha switches from addressing the monks as a whole to addressing just Anuruddha and his friends.

mn68:4.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ āmantesi:
mn68:4.3.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Anuruddha,

mn68:4.4.eng: “Anuruddha and friends, I hope you’re satisfied with the spiritual life?”

mn68:4.5.eng: “Indeed, sir, we are satisfied with the spiritual life.”

mn68:5.2.pli: Etaṃ kho, anuruddhā, tumhākaṃ patirūpaṃ kulaputtānaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitānaṃ yaṃ tumhe abhirameyyātha brahmacariye.
mn68:5.2.eng: It’s appropriate for gentlemen like yourselves, who have gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, to be satisfied with the spiritual life.

mn68:5.3.pli: Yena tumhe, anuruddhā, bhadrena yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā susukāḷakesā kāme paribhuñjeyyātha tena tumhe, anuruddhā, bhadrenapi yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā susukāḷakesā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā.
mn68:5.3.eng: Since you’re blessed with youth, in the prime of life, with pristine black hair, you could have enjoyed sensual pleasures; yet you have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn68:5.4.pli: Te ca kho pana tumhe, anuruddhā, neva rājābhinītā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, na corābhinītā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, na iṇaṭṭā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, na bhayaṭṭā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, nājīvikāpakatā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā.
mn68:5.4.eng: But you didn’t go forth to escape a summons by a king or a summons for a bandit, or because you were in debt or in fear, or in order to make a living.
mn68:5.4.comm: Also at SN 22.80:6.4 and Iti 91:2.4. The terms here follow the same sequence as in the Vinaya account of ordination. Generally, ordination should not be given in such cases, but if it is given, those performing it incur an offense of wrong-doing. | Soldiers joined the Sangha to escape military service, so the Buddha said one should not ordain those in service to a king (Kd 1:40.1.1). | Several rules regarding ordination of criminals were passed, the thrust of which is that wanted outlaws should not be ordained (Kd 1:41.1.1). | Another man ordained to escape debt (Kd 1:46.1.1). | “In fear” (bhayaṭṭa) is the only item that does not straightforwardly correspond to the Vinaya sequence, where instead the ordination of slaves appears at this point (Kd 1:47.1.1). But a connection is suggested by the verses of the water-carrier Puṇṇikā, who speaks of living “in fear” of her masters’ abuse and beatings. | Seventeen boys ordained as novices to get a nice livelihood (Kd 1:49.1.1).

mn68:5.5.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
mn68:5.5.eng: Rather, didn’t you go forth thinking: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn68:5.6.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti—
mn68:5.6.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering’?”

mn68:5.7.pli: nanu tumhe, anuruddhā, evaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā”ti?

mn68:6.1.pli: “Evaṃ pabbajitena ca pana, anuruddhā, kulaputtena kimassa karaṇīyaṃ?
mn68:6.1.eng: “But, Anuruddha and friends, when a gentleman has gone forth like this, what should he do?

mn68:6.2.pli: Vivekaṃ, anuruddhā, kāmehi vivekaṃ akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṃ nādhigacchati aññaṃ vā tato santataraṃ, tassa abhijjhāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, byāpādopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, thinamiddhampi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati uddhaccakukkuccampi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, vicikicchāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, aratīpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, tandīpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn68:6.2.eng: Take someone who doesn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that. Their mind is still occupied by desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, doubt, discontent, and sloth.
mn68:6.2.comm: This is the first absorption, lacking which the mind is full of hindrances. It appears that here the Buddha is explaining the benefits of absorption to Anuruddha, making this the first of several suttas concerned with Anuruddha’s meditative progress (MN 128, AN 3.130 , MN 31).

mn68:6.3.pli: Vivekaṃ, anuruddhā, kāmehi vivekaṃ akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṃ nādhigacchati aññaṃ vā tato santataraṃ.
mn68:6.3.eng: That’s someone who doesn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that.

mn68:6.4.pli: Vivekaṃ, anuruddhā, kāmehi vivekaṃ akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṃ adhigacchati aññaṃ vā tato santataraṃ, tassa abhijjhāpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, byāpādopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, thinamiddhampi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, uddhaccakukkuccampi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, vicikicchāpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, aratīpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, tandīpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn68:6.4.eng: Take someone who does achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that. Their mind is not occupied by desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, doubt, discontent, and sloth.

mn68:6.5.pli: Vivekaṃ, anuruddhā, kāmehi vivekaṃ akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṃ adhigacchati aññaṃ vā tato santataraṃ.
mn68:6.5.eng: That’s someone who does achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that.

mn68:7.1.eng: Is this what you think of me?

mn68:7.2.pli: ‘ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, appahīnā te tathāgatassa;
mn68:7.2.eng: ‘The Realized One has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.

mn68:7.3.pli: tasmā tathāgato saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodetī’”ti?
mn68:7.3.eng: That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and dispels some things.’”
mn68:7.3.comm: Of the seven methods given at MN 2:4.1, this omits “seeing”, “restraint”, and “developing”. The Buddha is asking whether his use of the four remaining methods gives the impression he is secretly acting from defilements. It seems to me that this question is speaking to a common tendency among young, idealistic practitioners to expect the teacher to completely transcend worldly activities. But then they see the teacher eating food (like someone desiring taste) or avoiding dangerous situations (like someone worried about their body). When they do such things, it comes from a place of attachment, so it is only natural to wonder if the same applies to the teacher as well. Someone who has experienced, at minimum, the first absorption has known what it is like for the mind to be temporarily free of such attachments, hence would not have such thoughts.

mn68:7.4.pli: “Na kho no, bhante, bhagavati evaṃ hoti:
mn68:7.4.eng: “No sir, we don’t think of you that way.

mn68:7.5.pli: ‘ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, appahīnā te tathāgatassa;

mn68:7.6.pli: tasmā tathāgato saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodetī’ti.

mn68:7.7.pli: Evaṃ kho no, bhante, bhagavati hoti:
mn68:7.7.eng: We think of you this way:

mn68:7.8.pli: ‘ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, pahīnā te tathāgatassa;
mn68:7.8.eng: ‘The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.

mn68:7.9.pli: tasmā tathāgato saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodetī’”ti.
mn68:7.9.eng: That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and dispels some things.’”

mn68:7.11.pli: Tathāgatassa, anuruddhā, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, pahīnā te ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
mn68:7.11.eng: The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn68:7.12.pli: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, tālo matthakacchinno abhabbo punavirūḷhiyā;
mn68:7.12.eng: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,

mn68:7.13.pli: evameva kho, anuruddhā, tathāgatassa ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, pahīnā te ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā;
mn68:7.13.eng: in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn68:7.14.pli: tasmā tathāgato saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti.
mn68:7.14.eng: That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and dispels some things.

mn68:8.1.eng: What do you think, Anuruddha and friends?

mn68:8.2.pli: kaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno tathāgato sāvake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti:
mn68:8.2.eng: What advantage does the Realized One see in declaring the rebirth of his disciples who have passed away:

mn68:8.3.eng: ‘This one is reborn here, while that one is reborn there’?”
mn68:8.3.comm: At SN 44.9 the six ascetic teachers are each said to do this, and the Buddha does it at DN 16:2.5.1 = DN 18:1.4. | This can be seen as a preemptive teaching to Anuruddha, who was to master the clairvoyance that makes such insights possible. The Buddha wants him to know that such abilities should only be used for pure reasons.

mn68:8.4.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
mn68:8.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn68:9.1.pli: “Na kho, anuruddhā, tathāgato janakuhanatthaṃ na janalapanatthaṃ na lābhasakkārasilokānisaṃsatthaṃ na ‘iti maṃ jano jānātū’ti sāvake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti:
mn68:9.1.eng: “The Realized One does not declare such things for the sake of fawning or flattering people, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’

mn68:9.3.pli: Santi ca kho, anuruddhā, kulaputtā saddhā uḷāravedā uḷārapāmojjā.
mn68:9.3.eng: Rather, there are gentlemen of faith who are full of sublime joy and gladness.

mn68:9.4.pli: Te taṃ sutvā tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharanti.
mn68:9.4.eng: When they hear that, they apply their minds to that end.

mn68:9.5.pli: Tesaṃ taṃ, anuruddhā, hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
mn68:9.5.eng: That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.

mn68:10.1.eng: Take a monk who hears this:

mn68:10.2.eng: ‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.

mn68:10.5.pli: So kho panassa āyasmā sāmaṃ diṭṭho vā hoti anussavassuto vā:
mn68:10.5.eng: And he’s either seen for himself, or heard from someone else, that that venerable

mn68:10.6.pli: ‘evaṃsīlo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃdhammo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃpañño so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃvihārī so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃvimutto so āyasmā ahosi itipī’ti.
mn68:10.6.eng: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.

mn68:10.7.pli: So tassa saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussaranto tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharati.
mn68:10.7.eng: Recollecting that monk’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, he applies his mind to that end.

mn68:10.8.pli: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuno phāsuvihāro hoti.
mn68:10.8.eng: That’s how a monk lives at ease.

mn68:11.1.eng: Take a monk who hears this:

mn68:11.2.eng: ‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.

mn68:11.4.pli: pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā’ti.
mn68:11.4.eng: with the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.’

mn68:11.5.pli: So kho panassa āyasmā sāmaṃ diṭṭho vā hoti anussavassuto vā:
mn68:11.5.eng: And he’s either seen for himself, or heard from someone else, that that venerable

mn68:11.6.pli: ‘evaṃsīlo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃdhammo …pe… evaṃpañño … evaṃvihārī … evaṃvimutto so āyasmā ahosi itipī’ti.
mn68:11.6.eng: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.

mn68:11.7.pli: So tassa saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussaranto tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharati.
mn68:11.7.eng: Recollecting that monk’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, he applies his mind to that end.

mn68:11.8.pli: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuno phāsuvihāro hoti.
mn68:11.8.eng: That too is how a monk lives at ease.

mn68:12.1.eng: Take a monk who hears this:

mn68:12.2.eng: ‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.

mn68:12.4.pli: tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karissatī’ti.
mn68:12.4.eng: with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, he’s a once-returner. He’ll come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.’

mn68:12.5.pli: So kho panassa āyasmā sāmaṃ diṭṭho vā hoti anussavassuto vā:
mn68:12.5.eng: And he’s either seen for himself, or heard from someone else, that that venerable

mn68:12.6.pli: ‘evaṃsīlo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃdhammo …pe… evaṃpañño … evaṃvihārī … evaṃvimutto so āyasmā ahosi itipī’ti.
mn68:12.6.eng: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.

mn68:12.7.pli: So tassa saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussaranto tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharati.
mn68:12.7.eng: Recollecting that monk’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, he applies his mind to that end.

mn68:12.8.pli: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuno phāsuvihāro hoti.
mn68:12.8.eng: That too is how a monk lives at ease.

mn68:13.1.eng: Take a monk who hears this:

mn68:13.2.eng: ‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.

mn68:13.4.pli: tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’ti.
mn68:13.4.eng: with the ending of three fetters he’s a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.’

mn68:13.5.pli: So kho panassa āyasmā sāmaṃ diṭṭho vā hoti anussavassuto vā:
mn68:13.5.eng: And he’s either seen for himself, or heard from someone else, that that venerable

mn68:13.6.pli: ‘evaṃsīlo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṃdhammo …pe… evaṃpañño … evaṃvihārī … evaṃvimutto so āyasmā ahosi itipī’ti.
mn68:13.6.eng: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.

mn68:13.7.pli: So tassa saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussaranto tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharati.
mn68:13.7.eng: Recollecting that monk’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, he applies his mind to that end.

mn68:13.8.pli: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuno phāsuvihāro hoti.
mn68:13.8.eng: That too is how a monk lives at ease.

mn68:14.1.eng: Take a nun who hears this:

mn68:14.2.eng: ‘The nun named so-and-so has passed away.

mn68:14.5.pli: Sā kho panassā bhaginī sāmaṃ diṭṭhā vā hoti anussavassutā vā:
mn68:14.5.eng: And she’s either seen for herself, or heard from someone else, that that sister

mn68:14.6.pli: ‘evaṃsīlā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṃdhammā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṃpaññā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṃvihārinī sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṃvimuttā sā bhaginī ahosi itipī’ti.
mn68:14.6.eng: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.

mn68:14.7.pli: Sā tassā saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarantī tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharati.
mn68:14.7.eng: Recollecting that nun’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, she applies her mind to that end.

mn68:14.8.pli: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuniyā phāsuvihāro hoti.
mn68:14.8.eng: That’s how a nun lives at ease.

mn68:15.1.eng: Take a nun who hears this:

mn68:15.2.eng: ‘The nun named so-and-so has passed away.

mn68:15.4.pli: pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyinī anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā’ti.
mn68:15.4.eng: with the ending of the five lower fetters, she’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.’

mn68:15.5.pli: Sā kho panassā bhaginī sāmaṃ diṭṭhā vā hoti anussavassutā vā:
mn68:15.5.eng: And she’s either seen for herself, or heard from someone else, that that sister

mn68:15.6.pli: ‘evaṃsīlā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṃdhammā …pe… evaṃpaññā … evaṃvihārinī … evaṃvimuttā sā bhaginī ahosi itipī’ti.
mn68:15.6.eng: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.

mn68:15.7.pli: Sā tassā saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarantī tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharati.
mn68:15.7.eng: Recollecting that nun’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, she applies her mind to that end.

mn68:15.8.pli: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuniyā phāsuvihāro hoti.
mn68:15.8.eng: That too is how a nun lives at ease.

mn68:24.1.pli: Iti kho, anuruddhā, tathāgato na janakuhanatthaṃ na janalapanatthaṃ na lābhasakkārasilokānisaṃsatthaṃ na ‘iti maṃ jano jānātū’ti sāvake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti:
mn68:24.1.eng: So it’s not for the sake of fawning or flattering people, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’ that the Realized One declares the rebirth of his disciples who have passed away:

mn68:24.2.eng: ‘This one is reborn here, while that one is reborn there.’

mn68:24.3.pli: Santi ca kho, anuruddhā, kulaputtā saddhā uḷāravedā uḷārapāmojjā.
mn68:24.3.eng: Rather, there are gentlemen of faith who are full of joy and gladness.

mn68:24.4.pli: Te taṃ sutvā tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharanti.
mn68:24.4.eng: When they hear that, they apply their minds to that end.

mn68:24.5.pli: Tesaṃ taṃ, anuruddhā, hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
mn68:24.5.eng: That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

mn68:24.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn68:24.7.pli: Attamano āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn68:24.7.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Anuruddha approved what the Buddha said.
